I always question my judgment when I sell portions of my holdings that I bought over my current average for little more than 1C in profit, but looks like I did good today with AMD per after hours trading. Finally knocked out some of my higher priced shares and Im in a better position with AMD than I was a week ago. The drop so far is now down back below my average. I will scoop up some more shares down here. Mm shares below my average mm gimme. I just trade expensive shares like this fractionally. I had worked up to AMD 6 shares usually in 0.1 increments as it dropped recently, then sold the upper half ASAP at bare minimum profit on the way back up. Now I just have 3 157 shares. Almost in the green with it still. Tempted to buy a whole share right now after hours. Edit Just to clarify since its not clear to me why Im being downvoted, my main focus is on building a strong position with shares bought below my average price. When I sell a few shares at minimal profit, its simply to reduce my cost basis by offloading higherpriced shares. This way, I hold onto shares I consider wellpositioned for gains, while ensuring my average cost remains as low as possible. The goal, really, is for every single stock in my portfolio to be green in terms of total gl, while at the same time, if things dont go well which they sometimes do not, trying to reach but not exceed 3k in realized losses. These are the incentives that have been put in place AFAIK, so Im just trying to maximize the possible utility within them.

... My aim isnt to capture large, taxable gains in the short term, but to incrementally improve my position, even if that means taking some small profits to optimize my cost basis. The crux of my methodrealizing minimal profits while rebalancing to keep my portfolio close to or below my average priceis actually aligned with tax efficiency, even if Im trading regularly. If it works with a lot of money, it works with a little bit of money. Strategically optimizing your positions doesnt depend on the size of the investment. I use fractional trading to test the waters and keep control of my gains and losses. You all seem to be misunderstanding my approach as merely chasing small gains when really its about building up a more resilient position in whatever I want to invest in long term. Also, no, Im not a wealthy Richy Rich type figure. I have some spare change and Im throwing it around as logically and mathematically rationally as I can.

Tesla includes reg credits in their automotive gross margins.

Regulatory credits are 100 income 100 corporate profit. Comparing the first 3 quarters of the year, their regulatory income is approximately 700 million higher than the previous highest year. Theyve pulled in about 1.7 1.8 billion in regulatory income in each of the last two years. Theyre on course to pull in 2.5 billion in regulatory income in 2024. Its a pretty massive chunk of their total net income for having to do absolutely nothing to get it save sell the cars they were going to sell anyways. Their net income through the first 3 quarters is 4.807 billion, versus 7.069 billion last year, or 32 lower yy. Remove the 700 million extra in regulatory credits yy, and it would have been closer to 4.1 billion or a 42 drop in income yy on their actual product sales. Theyre on course to just about match their total unit vehicle sales yy theyre still a bit behind last year through Q3. The problem is that their long term guidance which helped lead to the run up overvaluation in the stock price is 50 CAGR between 2020 and 2030. They rescinded that guidance in Q3 23 because they dont believe its possible anymore. To stay even with the 50 CAGR in 2024, theyd have need to sell over 2.5 million vehicles, but theyre on course to sell about 1.8 million. 2025 could see little if any sales growth versus 20232024. However, to maintain the 50 CAGR in 2025, theyd have to hit 3.8 million vehicle sales. Starting to see the problem? Their forward PE is based on crazy growth guidance, which even Tesla has admitted they cant hit, yet the stock is still trading at a forward PE of over 80. Most of the major OEMs across the world trade a forward PE of between 5 and 7. Teslas sales arent growing, their revenue isnt growing, and their income isnt growing, which means their PE is based on nothing more than a hope and a dream. It seems to me that for the second year in a row, Tesla will only see an annual profit on account of government subsidies and regulatory credit sales.
These credits wont last forever. Other companies wont let Tesla drink their milkshake forever.

Regulatory credits are the carbon credits they sell. Its not the federal state EV tax credit. They dont count EV tax credits anywhere since they dont receive them directly. Although... EV tax credits benefit Tesla in that Tesla can raise their MSRPs to offset the value of the tax credit, thus taking an equivalent amount of revenue profit

Yes, but the US is a fraction of the global market a significant fraction, but still. And EVs are a small fraction of the global market. The question is, will Tesla still be the leader or at least a strong 2nd place when EVs are 98 of the market. There will always be hobbyist and specialty use ICE vehicles, so itll never be 100 but it should be close. If you dont believe EVs are the primary future of passenger vehicles, you probably shouldnt be in Tesla in the first place, but there are hydrogen believers. Still. FWIW, I think its a strong probabilty that they will be. China is the only real concern, I dont see any serious challenge to Tesla dominance coming from anywhere else. On the other hand, China is doing well, and a governmentbacked Chinese company has ... not quite unlimited funding for expansion, but ... a lot. There is a real risk though that Tesla is regulated into failure in the US and Europe as political revenge for Elons activities, Teslas antiunion position, or both. If not actually shutting Tesla down with red tape, then subsidizing some competition that otherwise wouldnt be a viable threat. There has also always been a real risk that Elon says something intemperate that wrecks the China relationship China has a history anyway of letting foreign companies in to learn their technology before regulating them out or subsidizing the locals enough to push out the foreigners. It didnt happen that way to Apple and may not happen that way to Tesla if they also export enough Chinesemade product to be a net benefit for the Chinese... theres reason to be hopeful. Provided that Elon doesnt retweet any Winnie the Pooh memes, of course. Anyway, Im not selling my TSLA position, and odds are IMO reasonable, but it would be a mistake to think that dominating the emerging market in any way guarantees dominating the mature market.

Just to repeat from my last comment, and add a bit more info, regulatory credit isnt simple revenue... its 100 net income... 100 profits. 739 million is 33.6 of Q3s net income. Keep in mind, a massive chunk of their remaining net income comes from government subsidies. In the US for example, theyre still seeing 7500 federal tax credits on a large percentage of their total sales which allows them to maintain higher MSRPs, translating into higher profit margins. Most of their sales are in states with state EV tax credits as well, often in the 15002500 range. Some as high as 5000. Their energy sales are even more subsidized than their car sales. The federal government subsidizes something like 30 of the overall cost of a solar panel home battery storage installation. States with the highest rooftop solar adoption rates often have additional incentives on top. Overall, it can reach up to 50. Im not sure on their grid scale power storage, but Im guessing the subsidies andor the amount theyre charging the government, which often has mandates written into law to have storage installed, are lucrative. Like 2023... if Tesla were to exclude regulatory credit income and government subsidies from their income, theyd likely be reporting a loss for 2024. I guess this doesnt technically matter unless there were a risk that the subsidies were going to disappear in short order.. which theres no sign of. Some headwinds for Q4 Theyve removed their lowest priced trim model 3 near the end of Q3, which had the imported Chinese LFP battery. That could hit their overall sales numbers in Q4. It also means theyre not going to sell cars with the significantly cheaper LFP packs, which likely generated some decent profit margins. These units didnt qualify for the full tax credit on sales although I do believe they still qualified on leases, which Tesla would have had to roll into the lease price. Not sure if they did or didnt do that. They significantly cut the price of the Cybertruck and still dont seem to have a backlog after the price cut per their estimated delivery dates on their site. Theyve significantly cut the prices on their inventory vehicles. Model 3s Ive seen have up to 3k discounts applied. Model Y has as much as 4k discounts applied. Model Y accounts for the majority of their sales. That said, they were also aggressively discounting inventory vehicles last year in Q4. Theyre offering 0 financing offers which I believe is new this year. While this wont impact their unit sales, it will mean additional losses of up to 5k per vehicle over the course of the loan that they otherwise would have made on interest. I do expect Tesla to break their sales numbers from last year, if only because theyre so deeply discounting their vehicles. However, I expect their revenue and net income to be down in Q4 yy as a result of their deep discounting.

I used to work for a guy at a global logistics company. We were tasked with building something that had never been built before, using Machine LearningTM. The idea is simple. The theory is pretty simple. The actual construction of something that is as good or better than a human at performing a job.... Very difficult. We did not succeed and the project was cancelled. Now we were a motley crew to say the least most of my coworkers were Serbian and frankly not very intelligent. Nevertheless, I dont foresee the brightest minds solving the problem. I equate the problem of having a computer do human tasks like driving a car to putting a man on the moon, curing HIV, or harnessing nuclear fusion. The THEORY is straightforward. The implementation often requires the literal invention of new elements and materials in the case of NASAs Gemini, Apollo and Space Shuttle programs. So we know at a high level how to build FSD. I guarantee the guys at Tesla working on it have the theory nailed down. The implementation is what they are struggling with. Like driving, perfection is required to get people to and from space safely, cure HIV, or harness nuclear fusion. This is not shit that can be wrong half the time or even 20 of the time like ChatGPT. ChatGPT is childs play compared to FSD. Elon being an arrogant idiot failed and probably still fails to realize why FSD is more like nuclear fission than BonziBuddy.

Theres controversy about how some of them have both a ratings branch that rates stocks and sets price targets, and a branch that manages clients money. Legally they have to be separate from each other, but theres been plenty of times in the past when its stirred up controversy where one part of the company says Stock ABC is a great buy, while the other part is selling out of the same company. This is part of where the sentiment that its time to get out of a stock when Wall Street recommends buying it came from.

Intel is a massive opportunity with quite some risk attached. But if you are looking to 5x your money, this is prolly it. Most people have 0 clue what they are talking about when mentioning Intel Bad management According to reddit CEO Gelsinger is responsible for the failure of Intel. Although he will likely be the saviour of it instead. Intel is a massive slow moving ship that takes time to redirect. He took over from a bunch of MBA finance people with a lack of engineer background. These are the people that had Intel stuck in the mad and innovation was nonexistant. Instead they tried to milk every penny without innovating. Intel is too far behind Since Gelsinger a new strategy called 5 nodes in 4 years has been implemented. They currently are on schedule to make the deadlines. Normally Intel should be far behind the likes of AMD but if you look at their new sierra forest server processer they are unexpectedly on par with AMD. In the next two years they will also release backside power delivery which will be a massive innovation that TSMC hasnt pulled off yet. Intel is too far gone People would make you believe as if Intel is going bankrupt. Whilst in reality theyre creating lots of cashprofit if you ignore their fabs investment. They already secured 15bn in contracts from Microsoft for their 18a chips to be released in 2026. Remember they are on schedule and they are already testing these 18a chips. If they are succesful it will likely put intel on parity in semi fabs with TSMC. These chips are made by the newest semi machines. The ones that TSMC didnt want at first and eventually backtracked and got anyways after Intel initially got them. Intels moneymakers are still making money and will continue to make money. Although AMD has enjoyed a slight lead and was ahead of Intel for a while. Intel is just in time to catch back up and getting things back on track. Foundry is a whole different question. However, I think governments and companies have woken themselves up after the last Covid chip shortage. They realize they cannot be reliant on one manufacturer and need to diversify. Intel will play into that with their new fabs. The question remains if they can pull it off. My instinct would be yes. How in earth would they otherwise be able to compete with AMD in pricevalue for years after AMD went fabless? Although I dont see foundry adding a great amount of profits. Manufacturing isnt a highly profitable sector. But I think it will add enough value to get Intel to about 300500bn market cap. With the AI hype you could potentially add another 100200bn on top of that. But I think in 24 years the market will be calmed down and somewhat saturated and these crazy profit margins at NVDA will be gone.

Intel is cheap right now because their finances are a disaster, they are spending every penny they can make on building fabs that take multiple years to complete and they are trying to convince clients to give them a shot at making their chips with new fabs and new workers. The risks are if Intel has issues making sales that slows their ability to finance their fab construction which sets them back further. Intel needs the fab business to succeed for this plan to pay off. Also their chip sales slumped recently due to bad press about voltage issues which Intel was way too slow to address. They are laying off workers which may slow their ability to produce chipsrevenue and they suspended their dividend this month because they are hurting for cash. Their CEO is gambling the farm on the fabs working out and it might work out, or it may fail spectacularly, in which case Intel would likely go into a death spiral and cease to exist. Buying their stock is a risky move, keep it a small percentage of your portfolio if you invest at all.

Yea, i think they probably should have either focused on fab or design only, like most semi companies are pretty much specialized like you got SNPS design automation, NVDA design and software, TSM manufacturing then INTC is trying to do a little bit of everything which i just dont see working out well when theyre already probably 34 years behind

The new fabs should be competitive or even the most advanced in terms of tech, but not necessarily profitability. TSMC publicly held off on purchase of the most advanced lithography machines for a time because they said the sales opportunity wouldnt justify the CAPEX yet. Intel moved forward with it. But they are different companies and operational efficiency and practices like continuous improvement programs will determine who offers the better product for the better price or better margins, or higher yield. Theres a lot more to it than 100B of machines come in one end and profit comes out the other end, otherwise a dozen companies would be doing it. Intel does have a real chance here to pull ahead with the most advanced product and charge absurd margins to the right buyer. NVDA right now may be willing to pay double the cost per wafer even if it only makes the chips 10 more efficient, for example. The headwind is that INTC has higher labor costs by far, has a history of mismanagement and infighting that sure seems to be pervasive throughout many levels of the company, and they have to learn on the fly how to service customers dropping multibillion dollar orders instead of only working for an internal customer that can be bullied by top management. TSMC has been doing this for decades and customers know what to expect from them Intel needs new customers to go out on a limb and spend billions designing a product to use Intel silicon with the hope that they will deliver it in a couple years like TSMC does.

Basically just lined it out there, TSMC has also always had the biggest market share 45.5 in 2010 and parity to intel nodes, samsung has been in second place in the same time frame so Im not sure exactly what theyre trying to do with foundries.

CHIPS act is a definite advantage, but all it will do for Intel is subsidize costs a little bit. The real gamechanger would be customers like NVDA, NXP, AVGO, QCOM, AMZN, Meta etc choosing to pay more for US silicon because they perceive it to be safer than Taiwan or Korea but that really sounds unlikely. If US enacts some legislation that sectors like transportation, industrial, defense, aerospace, telecom must use US silicon, then all of a sudden INTC is well positioned and cost concerns melt away. Really its an unproven business model and we dont know if its going to work at all. I opened a small position after the last crash because it seemed like the market finally started to realize how difficult Intels path ahead is. I wasnt surprised by their earnings, dividend suspension and layoffs in the slightest.

replies.text: Im not sure youve gotten a straight answer on your actual question. This is all ignoring whether your allocation makes sense or not,. The answer is no, the specific accounts that investments are in doesnt matter when it comes to exposureallocation, what matters is your total overall allocation. When you decide on an allocation percentage, you should be thinking in terms of total of all retirement investments, no matter where those investments live. However, tax implications mean there are reasons to put particular investments in particular accounts. In particular, holdings that generate significant taxable distributions highdividend stocks or funds, most bonds should go into taxadvantaged accounts to limit tax drag. Holdings that are primarily capital gains e.g. growth stocks or naturally taxadvantaged e.g. municipal bonds experience less drag in taxable accounts. When rebalancing, you also want to do rebalancing within taxadvantaged accounts as much as possible to again limit the tax drag of realizing capital gains. This results in a couple implications 1. You generally want to keep bonds and other dividendheavy funds in taxadvantaged accounts like your IRA. Though there are exceptions to this if you arent really expecting bonds to grow perhaps not paying capital gains on the larger expected growth from growth stocks in a Roth would outweigh the tax drag from having bonds in a taxable account. How this weighs out depends a lot on how well you expect to be able to manage your capital gains tax rates and what your expected ordinary income tax rates are. 2. You also want enough of each of your components in taxadvantaged accounts that you can do necessary rebalancing purely within those accounts. 3. Otherwise just worry about total allocations across all your retirement investments. Note that you can still sell bonds for cash even if they are in an inaccessible IRA. You just sell stocks for cash from your taxable account, and simultaneously sell bonds in your IRA and use those proceeds to buy stocks in your IRA. This effectively is equivalent to selling bonds for cash, though there are potential implications around realizing taxable events.
deleted

20 bonds is very conservative at 36. Its not unreasonable, but its more than I would personally do. You should prioritize bond exposure in your taxdeferred accounts ie your trad 401k. Also, if youre over your IRA limit, you should prioritize your 401k over your taxable brokerage.

As far as your overall savings, it can be split up by savings goals, so x amount is for retirement and x amount for a house, etc. You would have different fixed income allocations for each goal based on how much time you have until you need to be able to spend the money. The aggregate of the different allocations for different goals tells you your overall allocation thats appropriate. Separate from that, or at least coexisting, is what money you have in different accounts. Money in tax advantaged accounts is inherently mostly for retirement because of the limitations on accessing it prior to retirement age, but money is fungible, meaning any dollar is the same as any other. Just because money in a 401k wont be spent until retirement doesnt mean it has to be invested like it wont be spent until retirement. If you have significant other savings in taxable accounts you may be better off putting most of your fixed income assets in tax advantaged accounts and holding mostly equities in the taxable accounts. The reason is that fixed income assets generate capital gains regularly, so in a taxable account youre paying tax on those gains every year even if you arent selling, but a tax advantaged account lets you avoid capital gains tax. If there will be a period where youll have lower taxable income in the future, like in between when you stop working and when you need to start taking rmds and social security, you can realize gains in a taxable account at a lower tax rate. Having only equities in a taxable account and needing to spend some of that money doesnt mean that youre relying on selling at a good price as long as you have the bonds or whatever to cover that expense in a tax advantaged account. Say you need to spend 20k and your taxable account is all in equities which happen to all be down significantly that year. If you sell 20k worth of stock to free up cash and at the same time, in a tax advantaged account you sell 20k worth of bonds and buy 20k worth of equities, then you effectively got that 20k cash from the bonds in your 401k and shifted more of your money into the 401k at the same time without the additional tax burden from actually withdrawing from the 401k. Im already my employer match on my 401k. When people say to prioritize an ira after getting the employer match in a 401k, that doesnt mean you shouldnt contribute further to the 401k if you have additional money to save for retirement. You should be hitting 401k contribution limits before considering saving retirement money in a taxable account. Prioritizing an ira isnt even always necessary, its based on the fact that a lot of 401k plans have high fees and not great options for funds. If yours is reasonable then go ahead and fully fund that before an ira. Also, 401k vs ira is another place that account allocation doesnt have to be the same as allocation for money dedicated to a goal. Often a sp500 is the cheapest option in a 401k and the sp500 represents about half the equities market, so you might have most of the money in your 401k in a sp500 fund and use the ira to get exposure to the rest of the market with lower cost funds. Your overall allocation for retirement money is still market weight or whatever your goal is, but within each account it can be very different.

The most common advise if your goal is retirement savings is to 401k up to match HSA IRARoth IRA 401k After match Taxable brokerage So you can increase your 401k contribution until you hit your max contribution of 23k , now if you want to investsave for some other purpose outside retirement the answer usually depends on how far out you will need the money want to buy a home in 5 years vs saving for your kids college in 18 years and your risk tolerance . However generally I am a fan to have similar allocations in your 401kIRA because it just makes rebalancing much easier . If your goal is to keep a 60 usa stock 20 ex usa stock 20 bonds if for example you go USA stock in your 401k bonds stock in IRA ex USA in taxable the problem with this is if your bonds go up and you want to rebalance is sometimes hard to do this as you may be limited , you cant really just pull out bonds from your IRA and put them in your 401k or something

It all depends on your goals. If this is all for retirement, then your 401k is going to be significantly more efficient than using a taxable brokerage. If you want money available for other future purchases preretirement, then the easier access of a taxable account may be valuable. As a quick example, assume marginal tax rates are 30 now and when you take distributions and that the capital gains tax is 20. Assume both accounts get 20 years of 7 annual real growth. 100 would turn into 271 posttax in a 401k, but only 217 in a taxable account. If you assume your marginal tax rate will go down when you take distributions usually the case this gap can widen even more.

replies.text: The number of funds in your portfolio is irrelevant what matters are the underlying assets. A single targetdate retirement fund, for example, can provide nearcomplete exposure to the investable stock and bond markets. There is no need to add complexity without a strong rationale. More complexity does not ensure better returns, and often, the opposite is true. Attempting to chase performance by overweighting individual sectors or markets currently hyped by the retail crowd is not a consistently successful strategy.

SpaceX and xAI are two different companies. The issue with ai is that the entire investing thesis is based on a misunderstanding of the underlying science. ML models work by determining the probability of results given a pattern. Despite popular belief, ML models cannot think critically like humans can. This has been proven many times in academic papers. The main takeaway here is that AI cannot reason through situations that do not follow previously trained patterns. The people leading tech companies are not computer science PHDs. They have MBAs, or are college dropouts that founded their company. So they are making huge decisions on AI investment without understanding the underlying science. Ai has some valid uses, but the business world is vastly overestimating its potential. They are mostly just copying each other trying to compete for as many gpus as they can order, kind of like how 34 years ago they went on a huge hiring spree competing for talent. Eventually they will cut back to trim their losses. SpaceX is also only afloat because of government contracts, btw. It is not profitable.

It is decent for writing small scripts, but it is unable to build or maintain applications that are more than a couple hundred lines of code. Once you give them more than a few requirements, they start forgetting older requirements and the product becomes a mess.

There is a mile wide gap between writing quick scripts that may or may not be functionally correct, and writing software. Lots of people are using AI to generate code snippitsscripts, and lots of it is bad. A great programmer will immediately identify those parts that compileexecute but have major logic flaws, but someone who doesnt know how to program is just going to end up having a bad day at the worst possible time.

There are a lot of really terrible programmers out there. Theyre also the most likely to try and use this AI stuff to write code for them, and least capable of identifying the flaws and errors.

If youre not proficient as a programmer, it is entirely possible your fully functional app has major logic flaws, efficiency issues, and other types of errors that are not immediately obvious. This may or may not matter to you depending on what youre using the output for. In a language like C, the devil is definitely in the details, and I would be very wary of AI generated code marshaled by someone with limited experience, especially if its doing anything of any complexity andor using parallelismthreading and dealing with locking.

Ranking of GPU Compute Power Among Major AI Companies 1. xAI Colossus Supercomputer Compute Power 200,000 NVIDIA Hopper GPUs after planned expansion Overview Elon Musks xAI is doubling its Colossus supercomputer from 100,000 to 200,000 NVIDIA Hopper GPUs, making it one of the largest GPUbased AI supercomputers globally. 2. Meta AI Research SuperCluster Compute Power 16,000 NVIDIA A100 GPUs Overview In early 2022, Meta formerly Facebook announced its AI Research SuperCluster RSC, which employs 16,000 NVIDIA A100 GPUs to accelerate AI research and development. 3. Microsoft and OpenAI Compute Power Estimated 10,000 NVIDIA GPUs Overview Microsoft built a supercomputer for OpenAI featuring 285,000 CPU cores and 10,000 GPUs as of 2020. Given ongoing investments and the scale of models like GPT4, its likely that their GPU count has increased, but specific numbers are undisclosed. 4. Google Compute Power Utilizes custom Tensor Processing Units TPUs Overview Google employs its own TPUs instead of GPUs. Their TPU v4 pods offer up to 1 exaFLOPS of compute power. While not directly comparable in GPU count, Googles infrastructure is among the most powerful for AI workloads. 5. Amazon Web Services AWS Compute Power Offers extensive GPU instances internal AI compute resources are not publicly disclosed Overview AWS provides a wide range of GPUbased instances for customers but does not reveal specifics about its own AI compute capacity. 6. NVIDIA Selene Supercomputer Compute Power Over 2,000 NVIDIA A100 GPUs Overview NVIDIAs Selene is used for internal research and was one of the most powerful supercomputers globally as of 2020.

I love SiC and WOLF, but I think the target within the next 612 months is a little high. Instead, I think 2030 is more reasonable. They basically doubled in the last week due to chips funding, but they need to execute. Execution primarily involves filling more orders and reducing CapEx, which they seem set up fairly well to do based on recent transcripts Ive readlistened to. They will have slightly higher manufacturing capabilities at the Mohawk Valley fab than they initially predicted. Overall, I like WOLF because they are the most experienced when it comes to making wafers of size. They are currently transitioning their wafer production from 150 to 200 mm, which is a great sign. On a more qualitative note, when I watch their YouTube podcasts, I feel that they get into the depths of the technology which I appreciate because to me, it shows that the scientists and engineers are leading the company. Other companies will for sure offer SiC in the future, but will they have the highest market share, Im not sure. WOLF is primarily focused on making the wafers, while sum companies focus on wafer production and device development. Only time will tell of course, my recommendation is to look into the tech and prepare for a moderately bumpy ride. After two years I project itll double and be around 3035.

No, they know what was supposed to happen, but they didnt follow it and didnt want to go through the full necessary process as it was too expensive. The door bolts can only be removed once the door has been removed. For obvious reasons, when the door is in place, there is no access to remove the bolts. However, removing then replacing the door would have mandated a costly reinspect. So the plane was sent back to get the door bolts replaced multiple times, but each time nothing happened as it would have required replacing the door and that was deemed too expensive because of the mandated inspection. Eventually the door bolts were replaced, and that was documented, even though the door had never been removed. How were the bolts replaced without removing the door? Nobody knows, its impossible. But somehow, thats what the paperwork says happened. So when the final check occurred to make sure things were done correctly, nobody checked to make sure all the door bolts were in place as they had been checked in the last inspection and since the door hadnt been removed they obviously couldnt have changed. Afterward they found four extra door bolts. Obviously someone either fudged some paperwork or didnt fully document what was happening.

I have am consultant in the aircraft industry for well over three decades. I have worked for all the biggest aircraft companies in the world, including Lockheed, Boeing and Airbus and at least 8 others. I have written class 1 software, DO178C DAL A, and achieved certification for that software on those aircraft. Additionally I have designed complete avionic suites inculding all sensors, integration and testing DO254. I have also been a developer for ILS and GPS systems. As a contract consultant I am totally capitalist, however even I know the importance of an experienced loyal workforce. I know the steps that have to have happened to fuck up that badly. The Flight Control Systems FCS are safety critical. They are class 1, DO178C DAL A. Nothing should interfere with their operation. Yet MCAS was allowed to overwrite the FCS. When you design a Safety critical system you use multiple types of sensors from multiple locations as input. MCAS used 1 sensor in 1 location and used this to overwrite outputs from the FCS. The amount of lies and fake documents produced to get that through the certification bodies is a lot! The whole reason for Boeing doing this is because the Airbus 320 family were using engines that were 20 more efficient. That is a big saving on the operating costs and customers liked that. Boeing had to change their engines to compete. They added larger engines which changed the position of the 737 centre of gravity. When this happened the Flight Control System FCS software should have been rewritten and retested. This would have cause around 12 months delay and around 20 million. Instead they came up with MCAS. That is inherently unsafe as it it one sensor in one location. They also never told the pilots about it as that would have meant retraining. They have now provided retraining however MCAS is still unsafe! The correct solution would be to change the FCS software. Yes I am totally serious. Each of the CEOs Muilenburg onward are no different from each other. The only hope is a 180 degree shift in position and I dont think that will happen. My prediction is that Boeing are in the shit. They will be split up and those parts sold of. Defence is worth having, someone like Lockheed or Airbus will take over commercial and space will be dumped. There will be other bits too. Most buyers will be unwilling but will be forced to take them. Current shareholders will take a bath! Good luck in your investments.

The customer puts a deposit on the airplane, when the airplane reaches certain milestones in the build engines are started for the first time, first test flight....etc another chunk is paid out, Ill give you a hint if you hadnt picked up on it yet. Management has asked machinist to do some really crazy things to hit these milestones sooner then they shouldve been reached for sake of getting said payout, like moving an airplane to the next position before its ready and asking a non door specialist to temporarily install a door, that was removed by a vendor without paperwork and said airplane get delivered and flies and said door departs aircraft. Finally the biggest chunk is paid on delivery.
Well said. I hope youre right about that.

And herein lies the core of the problem. If you view aircraft assembly as unskilled labor, you are probably qualified to be in executive management. I dont argue that theres plenty of unskilled labor jobs in all manufacturing settings, but if youre building an airplane, its not a matter of repeatedly hitting 4 lug nuts with a torque limited impact gun on an assembly line. You have to be able to read electrical, hydraulic, etc schematics and apply that information. You have to be able to reliable make precision measurements. You have to be able to read prints. You have to have to technical capabilities of reliably assembling one of the most complex pieces of equipment on the planet from a set of plans and turn that into a safe reality with a service life of 20 years or better. Engineering is a skill, and so is finance. But dont downplay the complex manufacturing process as unskilled, easily replaceable labor. Thats probably why fucking doorplugs are coming out. In my opinion, that attitude in general is truthfully what is destroying long term growth of manufacturing companies as their products become less and less reliable yet more complex as time goes on. this isnt exclusive to BA. But hey, we made a 5 savings on payroll this quarter, stock goes up, right? who cares that the place will crash next year.

What does any of that have to do with my point? If we are going to convey a narrative that the union workers are these suffering employees it should at least actually be true. It was a strategic move on their part to squeeze the company when they are down. They are free to try like anyone else but that doesnt mean it deserves sympathy.

Research how the original Henry Ford viewed paying his workers enough to afford the cars they were making. Take a look at wage growth in real terms for workers over the past 50 years vs productivity. Then do the same for CEOs and come back here and tell me the workers are overpaid.

Thanks for clearing that up. I suppose I had comments like this in the back of my head, which however indeed only say the bulk of a planes price is paid on delivery. It doesnt make to much of a difference in my opinion, since the milestones would still have to be achieved, if I understand you corectly? So no work on a plane no money from customers? My focus here is on this piece of information Boeing burned through nearly 4 billion in cash in the first quarter and West said that figure could be similar or possibly a little worse in the second quarter, but that the company would likely return to generating cash in the second half of 2024. Boeing had 10 billion dollar in cash after the second quarter and after taking up 10 billion Dollar in credit. I guess, we can safely assume, that their expectation of returning to generate cash in the second half of the year has evaporated with the strike. Meaning they are currently burning through that cash at a rate, which would see them illiquid possibly in December? They say, they have another 10 billion Dollar of lifeline, but by then their ratings may have significantly changed and they would also be at the very end of the line. The bottom line in my opinion is Boeing needs this strike to end. And it needs to do so fast. If it wants to have any hope for a recovery, it needs those workers on its side.
Yes 60 something on delivery

Geez do you think that every mechanic or flight technician is a flight engineer? My father is a retired flight technician. Basically a airplane mechanic. There are roles ranging from screwing and glueing on a production line to advanced engineering in building an airplane! Everyone isnt an engineer no matter how advanced the technology actually is in aerospace engineering!

That stuff is from a 2 year school, or learned on the job. its not anything special. Most of the time depending on what part of production they are in they are hitting buttons on a HAAS or a EDM etc, or running wires connecting them. youre giving them way too much credit.

BA is down because it made its own bed. They werent walking down the sidewalk, tripped over a crack, and then proceeded to get mugged by the onlookers. The earth didnt open a sinkhole under the Everette factory. And the entire management team didnt all get cancer at once. They made fundamentally bad business but temporarily good shareholder decisions for a long time. The strike, like all strikes, are politically charged and theyll be a lot of bullshit from both sides in the media about it. But my understanding is that most of the IAM members are not paid as well as you think they are, especially considering the cost of living in the area. Not remotely close. You can have all the sympathy you want for the company. But if they would have kept up with wages, training, and invested in RD and quality assurance in their products instead of 20 years of fucking stock buy backs, they wouldnt be kicked while theyre down right now.

I just posted a full explanation, but it got removed. Again Source The Economist The longedfor moment is almost here. For two and a half years, ever since Americas Federal Reserve embarked on its fastest series of interestrate rises since the 1980s, investors have been desperate for any hint of when it would reverse course. Now it would be a huge surprise if Jerome Powell, the central banks chair, did not announce the first such reduction after its ratesetting committee meets on September 18th. Indeed, among traders, the debate is no longer whether but how much. Market pricing implies roughly a 40 chance that officials will cut their policy rate, currently between 5.25 and 5.5, by 0.25 percentage points, and a 60 chance that they will instead opt for 0.5.Going by how investors have reacted to Mr Powells pronouncements over the past couple of years, you might think this is unadulterated good news for them. After all, Americas stockmarket has spent much of that time cratering whenever it looked like interest rates would stay higher for longer, and soaring on any suggestion that borrowing costs might soon come down. But it is not for nothing that buy the rumour, sell the fact is such an enduring mantra in financial markets. For all that the prospect of rate cuts sets investors pulses racing, their actual arrival has often proved disappointing.Consider how share prices have responded to past loosening cycles. Although the three episodes in the 1990s, when Alan Greenspan was at the Feds helm, did give the stockmarket successive boosts, this centurys record has been drearier. Rate cuts in the early 2000s took place during the bursting of the dotcom bubble those starting in 2007 coincided with the market crash that accompanied the global financial crisis. The doveish turn that began in 2019 buoyed share prices at first, but the effect was then swamped by the onset of the covid19 pandemic. Like so much in finance, rate cuts have a small effect on share prices in this case a positive one that is easily obscured by other factors. The fillip comes from a reduction in borrowing costs, which allows companies to keep more of their profits and encourages customers to spend more on their products. If bond yields also fall, prospective returns on shares become that much more attractive by comparison, providing another boost.What, then, might be the swamping factors this time? One is perennial that money never gets cheaper in isolation, but because central bankers fear economic weakness and want to stave it off. Just now, that seems like less of a worry than normally is the case. True, Americas labour market has cooled, which prompted a brief growth scare among shareholders over the summer. However, unusually for the end of a tightening cycle, the economy appears to be merely slowing down rather than entering a recession. Company profits should therefore be safer than usual as the Fed begins to cutand so should share prices.More worrying are the infamous long and variable lags, as named by Milton Friedman, between changes in monetary policy and their impact on companies and consumers. Counterintuitively, even as the Fed prepares to loosen, many borrowers will face steeper interest bills. Any firm that issued fixedrate debt while money was nearly free, which is plenty of them, will eventually need to refinance. Since there is little prospect of the Fed returning interest rates close to zero any time soon, debtservicing costs for such firms will be rising for some time yet. Homeowners on fixedrate mortgages who need to refinance after moving house, for instance will be in a similar position. So rate cuts may energise the economy, and hence the stockmarket, less today than they would have done in the past.The biggest hint that the Feds largesse will disappoint investors, though, is the extent to which it is already expected by the market. Already, traders central expectation is for 1.25 percentage points worth of cuts before the year is out, followed by another 1.25 next year. Such rapid moves have only occurred in the past amid recessions or crises. There is plenty of room, in other words, for Mr Powell to surprise on the hawkish side even as he slashes rates, which would raise bond yields and make stocks less attractive. Rate cuts ought to be good for the stockmarket. But not if investors have already pocketed their benefits. To get around the wall, install as an extension.

That or you just read the grizzly report and believed it I dunno. Bad Product...1000lbs heavier than Joby Its true midnight is heavier, but Id need more information to understand why this would strictly rule out competition with Joby. The Midnight airframe is very specifically targeted at slightly shorter operational routes and urban air taxi service compared to Jobys design. Additional weight could be for stability, passenger features, or the use of cheaper OEM parts instead of custom design. They have not demonstrated full flight. the video here pretty conclusively demonstrates a full size Midnight airframe flying. I would like more information about, specifically, the Flight Data Im aware Joby published data about noise in conjunction with NASA, but Im not sure if thats specifically what youre referencing here? Additionally, USAF took delivery of a functional full size Midnight airframe I am assuming that they would not take on a full size vaporware. Founders are business leaders vs technocrats Gonna be honest here, my entire OP is about why this isnt a bad thing, more on this in the next point. using too many vendors and integrating them is a huge problem. This is how the entire aerospace industry works, not a huge problem. Archer is able to source from so many companies because those companies exist as suppliers to aerospace companies already. this article covers the divergent strategies between ACHR and JOBY in depth Of note But when it comes to their specific manufacturing strategies, the two companies have staked out sharply different paths Joby is vertically integrated and largely develops its components and systems inhouse, while Archer is pursuing a more traditional model by relying on a roster of Tier 1 legacy aerospace suppliers. The article goes on to quote Adam Goldstein specifically saying that they are aware that an IKEA aircraft as you call it is an 80 solution but provides a significantly superior market entry point. Uber Elevates engineer is even quoted as speculating that Joby will eventually divest from its full vertical integration. nbsp Again, this point and both ACHRs quotes and the note that no aerospace company comes close to the level of vertical integration Joby is pursuing is exactly what my post is about ACHRs path to revenue is WAY more clean than Jobys Stellantis investment is all shares I cover this in my OP. ACHR has far fewer outstanding shares than Joby even after considering a 400m issuance to Stellantis through 2030. Their plant is going to stay idle for a long time Why? Even if theyre not fully certified when the plant becomes operational, ramping up will take time and they have a global orderbook including shipping to international customers which may have different certification timelines or requirements. Keep issuing more ESOPs and founder has left Admittedly, I dont know how significant potential dilution from this is, but usually, ESOPs arent so massive as to completely shift the dynamic of investing outcomes. The founder left to start new companies after having a fallingout with the board, yes, but he hasnt ever publicly trashed the company or even corroborated claims of it being a PR Scam so maybe he just didnt like it and went to do something else.

This leaves about 2.7bn and .8bn in speculative, long term, and IP patent, tech value respectively. nbsp Joby has fully acquired i.e. owns the IP H2Fly Hydrogen powertrain, Xwing autonomous flight, and Uber Elevate ElevateOS for ride ordering. Moreover, Joby has customdesigned nearly their entire airframe. When combined with speculative valuation from successfully entering operations, this value seems fairly reasonable. Even in a bear case, Joby potentially has multiple outlets to offer itself for acquisition or pivot to another method e.g. conversion of existing planes to hydrogen and autonomous flight. nbsp Given the IP disparity Archer designs its own battery packs and some other components, along with the actual airframe of course, my thesis is that Jobys IP and slight schedule lead are now diminishing in relative value compared to Archers actual business plan. Jobys IP stack is cool, but certifying custom build, and operational scaling are going to be harder than for Archer... With certification and operations set to begin next year, Archers superior orderbook and market plans should be valued equivalently to Jobys IP lead at this time. nbsp TLDR Joby fair value for their IP stack and superior product ACHRs superior market entry plan and order book should be worth more now, as risk of complete failure diminishes and likelihood of going to market increases.

Yeah Ive seen this and the only substantive issue, especially in the year since this report was published, may be the facility monitoring, Ill get back to that piece in a bit. Overall, and ironic considering their claims of ACHR being misleading, I find the report to be pretty deliberately misleading itself. Top line, Archer has clearly built and flown at least several completely functional Midnight airframes since that report. Regarding the USAF contract Archer has since delivered a fully functional Midnight airframe to the Air Force. Its true that they are behind Joby, but thats always been the case, and I am assuming neither the FAA Special Airworthiness Cert nor the USAF would take delivery of a scam product or vaporware at least, not a full airframe. The USAF potential order for airframes is not a substantial piece of ACHRs overall order book or operating revenue plans in any case, but I dont see why they wouldnt be able to deliver on the relatively small order if USAF continues to pursue it. They mention ACHR contracts with USAF related to autonomous flight and other highertech initiatives. I do find it likely ACHR will not continue as a leader in that space, as Jobys technology in these areas is indeed superior, as I mention in my OP. These contracts are a fraction 30M or less of the main eVTOL initiative there in any case. Highlighting these as potential losses is misleading in the context of ACHRs main business. Grizzly consistently mentions the dollar value of exercised warrants and share awards in the context of the obviouslyinflated price of August 23. While yes, those shares may be worth a considerable amount if ACHR succeeds in going to market, Grizzly leads with very large numbers attached to those share issuances while barely mentioning how unusual a price above 7 is for ACHR. Also as I addressed in OP, Grizzly talks up Joby throughout, but Jobys total share dilution is over double ACHRs total outstanding shares to this day. While there may be valid complaints about dilution, its outrageous to be in up arms over the issuances when a key competitor has done so much more. They obliquely imply that the companies investing in ACHR are doing so because theyre being given an opportunity to sell out of the company at the inflated share price. Stellantis has since continued to agree to investments in the company, with direct sharesforwork programs to ramp manufacturing. This is a pretty clear rebuttal of a number of points made by Grizzly. nbsp Regarding the manufacturing, flight videos, and overall progress being clouded ACHR has ramped up PR and specific posting of facilities and progress on the Georgia plant. Midnight clearly exists and clearly flies, including a more recent 10 minute unedited flight test video, an exact rebuttal of one of Grizzlys issues Where they posted a similar uncut Joby video. Its also a little odd that Grizzly was complaining about editing to make a flight appear longer in a video that was already only 042 seconds, which... okay? The source who claimed 2028 was Optimistic for certification is clearly not tracking how overall sector is making progress. If thats the case, Joby would be on target for 2027 at best also, and they have a complete custom ecosystem to certify, not just offtheshelf parts. Both companies, in the year following, are maintaining target times and presenting percenttocompletion that still targets 2025. It is possible still that Archers certification will be delayed to late 25 or 2026... I do find it worrying that they are still a little handwavey about their completely compliant for credit airframes being ready to go or in testing. I have addressed schedule risks several times when posting about the sector and ACHR specifically. That said, since August 23, their main Georgia plant is clearly progressing and they maintain the EOY timeline for completion as of this quarter. nbsp The claims about doing on site observation of the airport are at least interesting. However, its notable that the week they spent observing was exactly when the full size Midnight was built but not yet FAA certified. This timeframe lines up with the archer engineer saying they would have to wait as I find it rather plausible flight tests were paused between completion of the Midnight full size prototype and its airworthiness certification note that the continue to test flight daily were from prior announcements that occurred before their observational period I also have very little faith in the reports of supposed eyewitnesses when they are being asked about things by a literally activist shortseller company... Maker and Midnight are both quiet and small airframes, unique looking, true, but also short range. A full test flight could occur over the space of an hour or less, so even daily test flights may be missed routinely by people simply on the same airport grounds. Note that Grizzly did not consult or reference FAA Air Traffic Control, flight plan logs, or other possible authoritative sources for air time. Moreover, the empty facility they visited is very definitely online given that actual photo and video from the manufacturing process has been posted, and, again, at least several operational midnight airframes exist including one that USAF deemed acceptable for delivery. nbsp TO BE CLEAR I am not saying ACHR is definitely a superstar company thats going to be shitting out eVTOLs into the air taxi market next year... I just dont think that the piece published by Grizzly is a reasonable analysis.

First of all, if youre holding shares, you should be fine over a longer time horizon, this is around where we should bottom out... why ACHR is valued how it is right now Archer and JOBY, and all other eVTOL companies except EHang in china, are prerevenue companies. In other words, theyre spending money on RD but havent yet begun operations. Archer isnt actually selling or flying airframes commercially yet. As a result, traditional valuations such as PE, Dividend return, DCF, and other methods are either difficult or impossible to apply as a valuation mechanic. financial information such as cash burn rate compare to likely start of revenue generation substitute for this as a risk indicator. It does have generally nonbinding commitments for airframe sales valued at 6bn, as well as plans to selfoperate an air taxi service. Along with projected growth in the new Advanced Air Mobility sector, archer is theoretically well positioned for massive growth when operations do begin... Conversely, two major risks remain to getting operations. Most notably, type certification from the FAA saying the aircraft can fly passengers, and scaling of manufacturing supply chain and completion of main assembly line. Theres also a wider risk of a lack of infrastructure to support Air Taxis or the sector simply not catching on as something the public pays for. Essentially, the value of the company is then Possible major growth as a first mover in a new industry minus risk of catastrophic failure. Investing long term is saying Im parking money here knowing im speculating on success while short selling is saying i think the risks here are too great, and this company will fail before reaching operations. Why, specifically, its current exact value? Well, per my post, i have no idea and think its undervalued, so i am invested, but other people clearly have assessed the risk profile differently. nbsp As to why its red or green on any given day... its generally red and low priced when no catalysts or news comes out... Archer is very much on the hook to be much more concrete about its schedule, and soon, or the perceived risks grow a lot... many people are probably getting scared off by the relative lack of news given the supposedly tight timeline to start production. it goes WAY green when catalysts hit... new deals, timelines being confirmed, advances in certification progress, etc... that is, when the likelihood of future revenues increase and risks decrease and investors pile in. nbsp EOY prediction... Given the above and the fact that i am heavily invested in Oct and Jan calls. whatll happen? Basically two possible routes 1. ACHR begins for credit FAA type certification flights and proceeds quickly due to having mostly off the shelf parts i cover this vs Jobys custom build in my OP, and completes its Georgia manufacturing plant. If both of these occur by EOY, we probably go back to near 52w high 7 if not higher. 2. Any delays, setbacks, or major negative news occurs, or radio silence continues, and price continues to tank as investors look for shorter term gains and are unwilling to keep money parked in ACHR while it struggles to get running. nbsp Past EOY 24 to EOY 25 If they succeed in an entry in service date by EOY 25, that is, commercial operations begin, then we get to see an ASTSlike move in the price, as retail and institutions surge in on the hype train. This may be dampened a bit if Joby enters service earlier especially if Joby begins operations and encounters problems with operations We may see pops much earlier in 25 if nonbinding order agreements become binding as a result of Certification. 6bn in confirmed order backlog would be MASSIVE compared to 6bn in uncommitted orders. Conversely, if for credit testing begins but they faildelay for some reason, price tanks back to 3 range. If manufacturing plant has delays or failures, or production stalls due to supply chain issues, commensurate reduction in share price. nbsp Overall if you have shares you have several strategies Very long hold, as the Bull case through 2030 implies explosive potential 10x or more in share price, more if we get meme price spikes Sell on hype taking profits next time really good news comes out... then either be happy with that or rebuy when price slips between good news announcements. nbsp why do i have shorter term options? Well i have shares too, the short term options I play are very much gambling... but, as i describe above, this very speculative tech sector can see impressively insane hype spikes. Great news about beginning for credit testing or new orders or firm commitments, all trigger runs past 5 to 67. The time between now and EOY 24 is absolutely critical for the stated timeline and therefore speculative options could pay out massively. If price spikes, i also take out Strangles add puts to the mix to account for bad news and price drops.

Taxable income is the end balance after deducting expenses. Its below costs like R and D etc. Gross revenue COGS Gross profit Expenses incl SGA Net Income before tax Tax net income after tax or just net income This obviously varies by jurisdiction and type of company but its the gist of it, sort of like order of operations. You can have subtotals in there too like operating income but thats usually the same as net income before tax, it just doesnt include things like interest expense. If an entity has pass through tax then there just isnt any tax on the financials. Taxable income is not on the financials usually. Its on the tax return. Its usually close to net income but can be different. On the tax return you usually start with net income and then add or deduct various adjustments to convert the financial statement IFRS US GAAP net income to USA taxable income. For example maybe some marketing expenses are included in the financials but not tax deductible so that would be added back. Your overall thesis could be right. I just wanted to correct that one part in case it has flow through consequences for your analysis.

What is their cash flow? They can have negative earning due to things like accelerated depreciation and still have excess cash flow. Also, imagine they have to pay marketing and sales expense for new customer acquisition on a customer that signs a 20 year record storage contract. Negative earnings upfront, profit down the road.

EarningsNet income for REITs isnt a really accurate indicator of profit, because they claim depreciation on their properties every quarter, even though the market value of the properties is increasing. REITs like to record depreciation and other noncash expenses as much as possible, because theyre required to pay 90 of net income out as dividends. So keeping net income low means that they can retain more capital to use to expand their assets without relying as much on debt. The metric generally used to track REIT performance and ability to pay dividends is Funds from operationsFFO. This is essentially cash flow after paying for all overhead expensesupkeep, interest, etc. Iron Mountains FFO is 4.12 per year. Their dividend is 2.88 per year, so theyre paying out about 70 of their cash flow as dividends.

disturbing flatulence noises Consumer Spending Resilience While asset prices may decline, consumer spending is often buffered by factors such as savings, credit access, and fiscal policies like stimulus checks and tax breaks, which can sustain demand. Employment Dynamics High levels of employment are maintained by various sectors of the economy beyond just consumerdriven ones. Government and infrastructure projects, healthcare, and technology sectors often continue to hire and grow even during downturns. Government Spending Capacity Despite high current spending levels, governments can still leverage other tools like targeted fiscal policies, public investment in infrastructure, and tax incentives to stimulate economic activity without exacerbating deficits drastically. Federal Reserve Tools The Fed has multiple mechanisms beyond lowering interest rates, such as quantitative easing, forward guidance, and lending facilities to support economic stability and growth. Inflation Control The risk of significant inflation remains mitigated by the Feds capacity to adjust monetary policy quickly if inflationary pressures rise, thus maintaining a balanced economic environment. Asset Market Diversification While some asset classes may decline, others like bonds, safehaven currencies, and sectors like utilities or consumer staples typically perform well in downturns, providing balance and resilience to investors. Economic Cycles Economic downturns and recoveries are natural parts of the business cycle. Current policies and safety nets are designed to cushion impacts and promote quicker recoveries, reducing longterm adverse effects.

My only concern re point 3 is that the Blackwell Ultra may have to be redesigneddelayed as well. If the problem is overheating from connecting two Blackwells side by side, spacing them out or whatever solution they find, is more like a band aid solution as opposed to a fundamentally superior approach. Re point 4, selling 1 Blackwell GPU 1 CPU is not accelerated computing. The main product was 2 Blackwell GPUs 1 CPU, and lots of those in a rack. The performance of 1 GPU 1CPU wouldnt be competitive. No one would buy that. Also re point 4, it seems now almost certain that TSMC leaked it. They cant afford to have idle fabs to that scale. If Blackwell was supposed to generate 90b per year, thats 22.5b per quarter. If you use TSMCs 50 gross margin model, thats 10b impact to TSMC. They will be scrambling for work hence the leak. This way, instead of calling the industry and saying we have spare capacity, the industry can call them. AMD would be high up on the list. Re point 5, apparently the gaming GPUs have also been delayed...looks more structural than a 2 week fix. There is a point 6. If you apply a negative lens for a moment, and assume Blackwell starts shipping in Q1, and Blackwell Ultra needs to be fundamentally redesigned, it will mean that AMD from a hardware POV will launch products before Nvidia and again from a hardware POV they will be superior by a margin. Of course, CUDA is important, but reputationally and brandwise, Nvidia takes a hit. Also, CUDAs edge is that it enables Nvidia GPUs to perform amazingly. But what if someone elses hardware is noticeably superior? Doesnt that also weaken one aspect of the whole point of CUDA?
Now that all their best engineers are multimillionaires, do you honestly think their heart is in it to keep grinding? Expect more design and production issues and delays from now on.
